Singapore Management University" date: "2023-02-16" format: revealjs: width: 1600 height: 900 show-notes: false slide-number: true show-slide-number: 'all' date-format: "DD MMM YYYY" editor: visual --- ## What will you learn from this lesson? ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em"} - Typology of Interactive Techniques - Data & view specification - View Manipulation - Process and Provenance - Interactive Design Primitive - Animation: Principles and Best Practices ::: ## Building Block of Visual Analytics ![](img/image3-1.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Revisiting Visual Analytics Framework ![](img/image3-2.jpg) ## Taxonomy of Interactive Dynamics ![](img/image3-4.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: Heer, J. & Shneiderman, B. (2012) "[Interactive Dynamics for Visual Analytics](https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2146416)" ***ACM Queue***, Vol. 55, No. 4, pp 45-54. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - **Visualise** data by choosing visual encodings. - **Polaris** of Tableau ![](img/image3-5.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - **Filter** out data to focus on relevant items. ![](img/image3-6.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - **Slicer** is an axis-parallel selection tool, which selects a range along an axis, where the end-point of the interval can be modified dynamically. ![](img/image3-10.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: [crossfilter](https://square.github.io/crossfilter/) ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - **Sort** items to expose patterns. ![](img/image3-7.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - Hierarchical sorting ![](img/image3-8.jpg){fig-align="center" width="881"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Data & view specification - **Derive** values or models from source data. ![](img/image3-9.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Selection functions - **Pointer** selects a single object in a plot. ![](img/image3-11.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Selection functions - **Drag-box** selects a rectangular region in a box. ![](img/image3-12.jpg){fig-align="center" width="387"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Selection functions ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **Brush** is a generalisation of the drag-box. Once a rectangular region is define, the brush allows users to move that region across a plot and thus dynamically change the selected subset. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/image3-13.jpg){width="379"} ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Selection functions - **Lasso** allows users to define an arbitrary contiguous shape to select data. ![](img/image3-14.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Selection modes ![](img/image3-15.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Reference: [Mondrian](http://www.theusrus.de/Mondrian/) ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Highlighting - Selected records are highlighted. ![](img/image3-16.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation - **Navigate** to examine high-level patterns and low-level detail. - Shneiderman's mantra ![](img/image3-3.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation - The scatter plot provides an overview and the bar and line graphs provide detail sales and profits trends overtime. ![](img/image3-17.jpg) ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation - **Coordinate** views for linked, multi-dimensional exploration Scatterplot with marginal boxplot ![](img/image3-18.jpg){fig-align="left" width="495"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation ::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} - **Organise** multiple windows and workspaces. ::: ::: {.column width="70%"} ![](img/image3-19.jpg){fig-align="left" width="637"} ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: [VAST Challenge 2017 MC1 by Yifi](https://public.tableau.com/profile/yifei2012#!/vizhome/Updated1/VASTChallenge2017MC1) ::: ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### View Manipulation: Rotating ::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} - Touring view with JMP's 3D scatterplot ::: ::: {.column width="55%"} ![](img/image3-20.jpg){fig-align="left" width="556"} ::: ::: ## Process and Provenance ::: {style="font-size: 1.2em"} - **Record** analysis histories for revisitation, review and sharing. - **Annotate** patterns to determine findings. - **Share** views and annotations to enable collaboration. - **Guide** users through analysis tasks or stories. ::: ::: notes Visual analytics is not limited to the generation and manipulation of visualizations---it involves a process of iterative data exploration and interpretation. As a result, visual analytics tools that provide facilities for scaffolding the analysis process will be more widely adopted. Tools should preserve analytic provenance by keeping a record of analyst actions and insights so that the history of work can be reviewed and refined. ::: ## Interactive Design Primitive A framework for effective interactive design in visual analytics application. ![](img/image3-21.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: Roth, R.E. (2012) "Cartographic Interaction Primitive: Framework and Synthesis". The Cartographic Journal, Vol. 49, No. 4 pp. 376-395. ::: ## Interactive Design Primitive ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Visual Analytics Objective Primitives ![](img/image3-22.jpg) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Interactive Analytics Operator Primitives ![](img/image3-23.jpg) ::: ::: ## Interactive Design Primitive ![](img/image3-24.jpg) ## Animation in Visual Analytics ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - The purpose of animation is to facilitate perception of changes when transitioning between related data graphics - Do not confine to time-series data only ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/image3-25.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: [How Many Households](http://worrydream.com/HowManyHouseholds/) ::: ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Why using Animation in Visual Analytics ::: {style="font-size: 1.2em"} - Motion is highly effective at attracting attention. - Animation facilitates object constancy for changing objects. - Animated behaviours can give rise to perceptions of causality and intentionality, communicating cause-and-effect relationships and establishing narrative. - Animation can be emotionally engaging, engendering increased interest or enjoyment. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Principles of Animation ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - ***Congruence*** principle states that the structure and content of the external representation should correspond to the desired and content of the internal representation. - Maintain valid data graphics during transitions - Use consistent semantic-syntactic mappings - Respect semantic correspondence - Avoid ambiguity ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - ***Apprehension*** principle states that the structure and content of the external representation should be readily and accurately perceived and comprehended. - Group similar transitions - Minimise occlusion - Maximise predictability - Use simple transitions - Use staging for complex transitions - Make transitions as long as needed, but no longer ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: Heer, J and Robertson G. (2007) [Animated Transitions in Statistical data Graphics](https://idl.cs.washington.edu/files/2007-AnimatedTransitions-InfoVis.pdf), IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, Vol. 13, No. 6, 1240-1247 and the [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vLk7mlAtEXI). ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Animation in Action ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Stacked-to-Grouped Bars ![](img/image3-26.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: [Stacked to Grouped Bars](https://observablehq.com/@d3/stacked-to-grouped-bars) ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### Animated Co-occurrence matrix ![](img/image3-27.jpg) ::: {style="font-size: 0.65em"} Source: [Miserables](https://bost.ocks.org/mike/miserables/) ::: ::: ::: ## References - [Dynamics for Visual Analysis](https://idl.cs.washington.edu/files/2012-InteractiveDynamics-CACM.pdf) - [Animated Transitions in Statistical Data Graphics](https://idl.cs.washington.edu/files/2007-AnimatedTransitions-InfoVis.pdf), IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, Vol. 13, No. 6, 1240-1247 and the [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vLk7mlAtEXI) - [Coordinated Highlighting in Context](http://www.perceptualedge.com/articles/visual_business_intelligence/coordinated_highlighting_in_context.pdf) - [Cartographic Interaction Primitive: Framework and Synthesis](https://web-a-ebscohost-com.libproxy.smu.edu.sg/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=16eab3bc-b4a2-47b5-9a03-2619822e5ddb%40sessionmgr4007) ::: {.cell} :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
